awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Recovery and Transformation of Human Mobility Traces for Mobile Wireless Experimentation
awd_abstract_narration: The advent of cheap, ubiquitous, portable, multi-radio devices means that mobile wireless networking will be the predominant future method for network access and edge network formation. Many of these devices will have mobility that is dictated by the movement of the humans who carry them. Hence, capturing real-world human mobility patterns is essential for improving our understanding of the new networks and communication opportunities that will arise. However, even small-scale measurements carry a significant organizational overhead in preparing, distributing and collecting contact loggers, not to mention non-technical issues related to legality and participant consent. This research program addresses two key issues:  the recovery of mobility information from contact traces, and the transformation of traces collected under one set of circumstances to realistic alternative scenarios. The basis for the recovery work is a dynamic, force-based heuristic to recover plausible mobility from a contact trace. The basis for the transformation techniques is the combination of the original trace and the plausible mobility, plus models for real-world alternative settings. In both cases, the work addresses fundamental questions about efficient computational methods and the limits to computational capability for recovery and transformation. Answers to these two questions will allow researchers to collect and transform traces so as to extract maximum value from expensive measurement methods, enabling trace-driven simulation of mobile wireless networks to play a central role beside analysis and direct experimentation. In addition, the trace collection experiments used in validation will provide a valuable resource to researchers in mobile networking.

por.por_cntn:
People increasingly use smart phones, tablets and laptops while they are moving, whether walking down a street or riding in public or private transportation. These mobile devices assist users in communicating by voice or text, and in performing computations, such as providing advice on the best route from one location to another. Supporting communication and computation while devices are moving is significantly challenging. Many researchers in academia and industry propose and evaluate ideas to make mobile communication and computation work better than they do today.  

Two key concepts are vital to evaluating ideas for how to make mobile devices better. First, it is important to have “models” for how mobile users move around. These models describe movement in a concise way. Good models provide a reasonably accurate approximation of real movement and make evaluation better. Second, it is important to understand new settings where mobile devices might be used, now and in the future.

Our work has contributed to better models for mobility by developing methods to infer mobility from information about which mobile nodes are in communication distance of one another. These methods make it easier to build good mobility models. We have also contributed to understanding a new setting for mobile devices, one where there is a powerful computer (or several such computers) nearby. This might happen in a military setting or in a disaster scenario where a powerful computer can be positioned near less powerful mobile devices. We have developed algorithms to control how the powerful computer might move around in a setting to visit mobile devices and assist with complex computation tasks such as image recognition that cannot be completed by the mobile device alone. In doing this work, we have developed a simulation that can be used to study many variations of this basic problem, and we have shared that simulation code with others.

We are committed to increasing diversity in STEM fields. One of the PIs for this project is a female computer science faculty member who regularly participates in local and national panels related to women in computer science. One part of the inferring mobility work took place in the summer as part of an internship program developed by one of the PIs on Data Science for Social Good (DSSG). DSSG places students in teams to work on projects with a social good theme. Anecdotal evidence suggests that female students are drawn to computing projects that make a strong connection to real world concerns.
